Project Description  The Project has three investment components: energy efficiency 
improvement, renewable energy development, and access for the 
poor.  
 
The  energy  efficiency  improvement  component  will  include 
(i) system control modernization (part 1); (ii) transmission system 
strengthening (part 2); (iii) distribution substations augmentation 
(part  3);  (iv)  demand-side  management  for  municipal  street 
lighting (part 4); and (v) consulting services for system control 
modernization (part 5).  
 
The  clean  energy  development  component  will  be  network 
capacity augmentation for renewable energy projects (part 6).  
 
The access for the poor component will include (i) transmission 
system strengthening in the Eastern Province (part 7) and (ii) rural 
household connection (part 8).  
   
Rationale  Sri Lanka’s power sector struggled throughout the late 1980s, 
1990s,  and  early  2000s  to  meet  the  growing  demand  for 
electricity.  Electricity  is  expensive  and  subject  to  interruptions. 
About 20% of households do not have access to it. The Ceylon 
Electricity Board is burdened with debt, restricting its ability to 
make capital investments and discouraging private investment. 
The Government is fully committed to addressing these issues 
and has developed a Ten-Year Development Framework (TYDF). 
Under  the  TYDF,  the  Government  has  developed  a  national 
energy  policy  and  strategies  (NEPS).  The  NEPS  provides  a 
comprehensive road map for the sector. It includes a long-term 
investment program and specific policy and reform measures and 
aims to (i) supply electricity to 86% of households by 2010 and 
98% by 2016, and (ii) ensure electricity tariffs are competitive with 
those in other countries and sufficient for utilities to be viable. 
 
 
  Under the NEPS, the Government is accelerating its long-term 
generation  expansion  plan  (LGEP)  to  build  up  generation 
capacity, primarily with bilateral funding. At the same time, it is

ii   
continuing its loss reduction efforts and launching a demand-side 
management program to improve energy efficiency. Substantial 
investments  will  be  required  to  strengthen  the  transmission 
network  and  for  power  plants.  The  huge  potential  for  energy 
conservation  through  demand-side  management  needs  to  be 
more actively tapped. 
 
The share of thermal  power in the power generation mix has 
increased dramatically from 1% in 1986 to 58% in 2008 as the 
entire  demand  growth  has  been  served  by  oil-fired  thermal 
generation. This poses a serious threat to the country’s energy 
security  as  well  as  to  the  environment,  given  Sri  Lanka’s 
overdependence on imported fossil fuels. Coupled with fuel price 
increases and the delayed construction of new hydropower plants, 
generation costs have substantially increased. There is an urgent 
need to develop clean energy and indigenous renewable energy 
sources.   
 
To achieve the electrification target under the TYDF, particular 
attention  needs  to  be  paid  to  regions  with  serious  power 
shortages and many unconnected households, including conflict-
affected areas. The transmission system is currently too weak to 
meet growing demand in the regions. Despite the Government’s 
intensive  investment  program  to  expand  the  rural  distribution 
network,  many  poor  households  remain  unconnected  even  in 
areas connected to the grid because they cannot afford the initial 
cost of service connection.  
 
The Project will support the Government to address these issues 
through  investment  loans  and  grant  and  associated  technical 
assistance.   
 
The Government has taken measures to strengthen governance 
and  rationalize  tariffs.  The  Sri  Lanka  Electricity  Act  has  been 
passed by Parliament in March 2009. It will empower the Public 
Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) to regulate the power 
sector.  To  restore  the  financial  viability  of  the  sector,  the 
Government has restructured the debt of the Ceylon Electricity 
Board (CEB) and raised tariffs by 30% in 2008 to reduce its cash 
shortfall  substantially.  The  Project  will  support  further 
strengthening  of  the  governance  of  the  sector  through  its 
associated  technical  assistance  for  capacity  development  of 
PUCSL and CEB.   
 
Impact and Outcome  The  Project  aims  to  realize  an  affordable  and  reliable  power 
supply for sustained and inclusive economic growth by improving 
the  coverage  and  service  efficiency  of  the  CEB  and  Lanka 
Electricity Company (LECO).

Implementation  The Ministry of Power and Energy (MOPE) will be the Executing 
Arrangements  Agency of the Project. CEB will be the sole Implementing Agency 
for  all  investment  parts  except  for  distribution  substations 
augmentation  (part  3)  and  demand-side  management  (part  4) 
parts which will be implemented jointly by CEB and LECO. Day-
to-day  project  implementation  will  be  done  by  project 
implementation  units  (PIUs)  to  be  set  up  in  CEB  and  LECO 
exclusively for the Project and headed by senior officers.   
 
The  distribution  substations  augmentation  part  will  be 
implemented  initially  by  LECO,  and  subsequently  the  project 
assets and associated debt will be transferred to CEB, who will 
undertake operation and maintenance.  
 
The demand-side management part will be implemented by both 
CEB  and  LECO  in  their  respective  jurisdictions.  Once  MOPE 
issues a policy circular to delegate responsibility for municipal 
street lighting in selected areas from municipal authorities to CEB 
and LECO, they will establish internal energy service company 
(ESCO) units within which escrow accounts will be established to 
accumulate energy savings gains. The associated ADB technical 
assistance  will  help  them  to  do  this.  Upon  completion  of  the 
payback period, energy savings will create a revenue stream in 
addition to that generated through tariffs. It is envisioned that a 
certain percentage of energy savings profits accumulated at the 
escrow  account  will  be  used  for  reinvestment  in  other  energy 
efficiency  projects  identified  by  the  ESCO  unit  as  part  of  its 
operational responsibilities.  
 
  The rural household connection part will be implemented by CEB 
with  the  support  of  service  providers  to  be  engaged  under  a 
performance-based contract on terms and conditions acceptable 
to ADB.  When a credit application is submitted to CEB from a 
customer  household,  a  service  provider  will  assess  the 
household’s  repayment  capacity,  while  CEB  will  confirm  the 
technical eligibility of electricity connection. If the application is 
approved,  CEB  will  provide  a  service  connection  and  the 
connection cost will be recorded as a loan to the customer in 
CEB’s balance sheet and recovered in installments over the next 
24–36  months.  An  escrow  account  will  be  set  up  in  CEB  to 
receive  installment  payments.  Principal  and  interest  payments 
from  households  will  be  credited  to  the  account  and  used  to 
provide  new  installment  credits.  ADB  will  provide  associated 
technical assistance for the detailed design of the part, selection 
of service providers, and capacity building of major stakeholders.

80:20 and in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of

Project Benefits and  The energy efficiency improvement component will enhance the 
Beneficiaries  overall reliability of the power system to benefit households, small 
and medium-sized businesses, and public services, including, in 
particular, schools and hospitals. It will bring power to industrial 
districts  where  existing  industries  currently  relying  on  captive 
generators  will  be  able  to  improve  their  productivity.  New 
investments will also be encouraged by the additional availability 
of power. In both cases, a sharp increase in labor demand is 
ultimately  expected  to  benefit the local population. The demand- 
side management part is expected to save energy equivalent to a 
thermal  power  plant  of  3.5  MW.  The  renewable  energy 
development  component   will   help   bring  200   MW   of   clean 
hydropower energy into the grid, thereby reducing CO -equivalent

  The access for the poor component will contribute to social and 
economic inclusion and the integration of the marginalized people, 
especially in rural areas. Health, hygiene, and sanitation will be 
improved. Children and adolescents will be able to spend more 
hours  studying.  The  component  will  improve  access  to 
information, awareness and knowledge. It will enhance mobility 
and security, particularly where people suffer from attacks by wild 
animals while searching for food or where they are affected by the 
conflict.  Electrification will  enable poor  households  engaged  in 
home-based  economic  activities  to  generate  more  household 
income and to save time and physical labor by using electrical 
appliances. The rural household connection part will connect at 
least 60,000 poor households (8% of the total) to the grid.  
 
  The  access  for  the  poor  component  will  directly  benefit  the 
Eastern  Province,  which  has  been  severely  affected  by  the 
conflict, and other poor regions. Such regions often suffer from 
harsh weather and natural disasters, and lack basic infrastructure, 
including  electricity  distribution.  Three  districts  in  the  Eastern 
Province where the component will be implemented have mixed 
Sinhalese, Tamil, and Muslim populations, and are therefore more 
complex than other parts of the country. The Project will directly 
contribute to the development of the Eastern Province, but will 
also benefit other regions that are lagging behind.  
   
Risks and Assumptions  The major assumptions are that (i) the Government will remain 
committed to power sector reforms; (ii) LGEP will be implemented 
in a timely manner; and (iii) the Sri Lanka Electricity Act will be 
efficiently implemented for PUCSL to regulate the sector. 
  
The Government’s commitment to sector reform is demonstrated 
by  the  fact  that  it  has  (i)  provided  financial  support  for  the 
implementation  of  CEB’s  long-term  debt  restructuring  plan; 
(ii) submitted the NEPS for parliamentary approval, which is not 
required  for  a  policy  document,  and  gazetted  it;  and 
(iii) substantially increased retail tariffs to improve CEB’s financial 
position. CEB has drafted its first long-term corporate plan, which 
it  is  using  as  a  basis  for  its  internal  reform  exercise.  The 
Government has already secured financing for the priority projects 
in  LGEP  and  three  projects  totaling  950  MW  are  being 
implemented. 
 
Parliament has passed the Sri Lanka Electricity Act in March 2009 
and PUCSL has started regulating the power sector. Although 
there is a risk that PUCSL and CEB will lack the capacity to 
operate effectively under the new regulatory framework, this will 
be  substantially  mitigated  by  ADB’s  technical  assistance  for 
capacity  development  of  the  two  agencies  and  PUCSL’s 
experience in supporting the Government’s policy-making over the 
past 4 years.

vii
   
Other  risks  to  the  implementation  of  the  investment  projects 
include (i) delays in associated generation investments, (ii) delays 
in project implementation and resulting project cost escalation, 
and (iii) a deterioration in the security situation in the Eastern 
Province.  These  risks  also  appear  to  be  low.  A  policy  and 
regulatory  framework  is  already  in  place  to  streamline  the 
Government approval process for renewable energy projects. The 
Sustainable Energy Authority (SEA) has been established as a 
focal  agency  for  renewable  energy  development  and  is  being 
supported by ADB TA to expedite the review of the pending small 
hydropower projects that will be promoted by the Project. All the 
subprojects under the Project are ready for implementation and 
advance procurement will help expedite project implementation 
and mitigate risk of cost overruns. As the Government is now 
taking full control of Eastern Province, no difficulty is foreseen in 
implementing  the  subprojects.  The  associated  technical 
assistance will also help to design implementation arrangements.   
 
Technical Assistance  TA  grants  will  be  provided  for  advisory  assistance  to  the 
Government  in  (i)  Capacity  Development  for  Power  Sector 
Regulation—to provide capacity development support for PUCSL

(ii) Demand-Side  Management  of  Municipal  Street  Lighting—to

II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
2.  Sri Lanka’s power sector struggled throughout the late 1980s, 1990s, and early 2000s to 
meet the growing demand for electricity. Given that demand for power is growing by about 8% 
per  year,  the  country  faces  a  serious  shortage  of  power  and  a  consequent  slowdown  of 
economic growth unless generation capacity is significantly increased and the transmission and 
distribution  network  is  strengthened.  Sri  Lanka’s  national  electrification  ratio 2  improved 
significantly from 10.9% in 1986 to 82% in 2008 and compares favorably with those in other 
South Asian countries. However, substantial disparities in access to electricity still exist. As of 
the end of 2008, per capita electricity consumption was about 492 kilowatt-hours (kWh), lower 
than in India and Pakistan. System losses are estimated at 15%. While this is relatively low 
compared to the average of  South Asia, there is still room to reduce losses by another 4%–5%.  
 
3.  In  Sri  Lanka,  the  total  power  generation  capacity  available  to  the  grid  was  
2,580 megawatts (MW) at the end of 2008. Of the total energy provided to the grid, 37.4% is 
hydropower, 58.2% is thermal (oil), and 4.4% is nonconventional renewable energy. Ceylon 
Electricity Board (CEB) and Lanka Electricity Company (LECO) are the only two utilities in the 
power sector. CEB, an integrated utility fully owned by the Government and engaged in the 
generation, transmission and distribution of electricity, has an installed generation capacity of 
1,725 MW, serving about 90% of all customers. LECO was formed as a distribution company 
under the Companies Act and most of its shares are owned by CEB and the Government. 
Municipal authorities are minority shareholders. LECO purchases bulk power from CEB and 
distributes it to about 400,000 consumers in other urban areas in the western and coastal belt, 
representing about 10% of all consumers. The private sector is currently only in the generation 
sector and has a total capacity of 705 MW. 
 
B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
1.  Key Problems 
 
4.  In  Sri  Lanka,  electricity  is  expensive  and  subject  to  interruptions.  About  20%  of 
households do not have access to it. CEB is burdened by debt, restricting its capacity to make 
capital investments and discouraging private investment.

5.  High Cost of Generation. The share of thermal power in the power generation mix has 
increased dramatically from 1% in 1986 to 58% in 2008 as the entire growth in demand has 
been served by oil-fired thermal generation. The 1998 policy of building thermal power plants 
with private financing has resulted in a proliferation of relatively small high-cost oil-fired plants. 
Political decisions and lack of financial resources have prevented CEB from implementing the 
least-cost generation plan, which is to use coal as it is the most economic source of energy. The 
move toward oil-fired plants, the increase in the oil price, and the delayed construction of new 
hydropower plants have significantly pushed up the cost of generation. There is an urgent need 
to build up base-load generation capacity with low-cost fuels such as imported coal and to 
invest in hydropower and other renewable resources. 
 
6.   Skewed Tariff Structure. The dramatic increase in generation costs since 1998 has 
not been passed on to electricity consumers since the Government, as the regulator, has had 
neither the political will to pass on the cost increases to consumers nor the technical capacity to 
evaluate the CEB’s cost structure to decide on the appropriate level of tariffs. As a result, CEB 
has posted an operating loss since 2000 and accumulated its liability. Sri Lanka’s electricity 
customers, particularly commercial and industrial customers and large households, pay higher 
prices than most of their regional comparators. A reduction in the cost of supply is urgently 
needed, coupled with a stable and high-quality supply of electricity. 
 
7.  Inadequate and Aging Transmission and Distribution Network. Retail tariffs, which 
do not reflect the cost of supply, coupled with delays in project implementation, have continued 
to squeeze its investments in transmission and distribution. The low-voltage distribution network 
requires improvements if it is to meet the expansion in housing and commercial developments. 
Overdue investment in the medium-voltage distribution network has caused overloading, poor 
reliability and fluctuating voltage at many locations. The growth in demand for power distributed 
over the medium-voltage network requires a matching investment in the transmission network 
and grid substations. Immediate investments in the transmission and distribution network are 
needed, not only to reduce system losses and to ensure the stability of the entire power system, 
but also to encourage private sector investment in nonconventional renewable energy.   
   
8.  High Commercial Losses and Lack of Penetration in Rural Areas. The low customer 
density in suburban and rural areas causes higher network losses than in urban areas. In 
parallel with network strengthening, further efforts are needed to upgrade and improve meters 
and  metering  systems  and  to  enforce  strict  surveillance  to  prevent  theft.  Another  major

measures. It aims to (i) supply electricity to 86% of households by 2010 and 98% by 2016, and

11.  Enabling  Regulatory  Environment  and  Sector  Reforms.  The  Government 
established the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) in 2002 as a regulator for 
energy and water sectors under the PUCSL Act 2002. The Electricity Reform Act, 2002, was

Parliament in March 2009 to replace the Electricity Reform Act.  
 
12.  CEB  Corporate  Plan  and  Functional  Business  Unit.  CEB  has  converted  its 
generation, transmission, and distribution operations into six functional business units (FBUs) 
(one for generation, one for transmission, and four for distribution). Financial accounts have 
been segregated so that each FBU will operate as a profit center. CEB has developed a long-
term corporate plan that sets strategic objectives for each FBU based on a corporate vision and 
goals. The corporate plan will be a basis for its internal reform exercise. The performance of 
each FBU will be measured by key performance indicators to be identified under the corporate 
plan. Performance of each FBU will also be monitored by PUCSL through its conditions to grant 
licenses to CEB. The corporate plan will also identify those functions that will be decentralized 
to the FBU level and those that will be centralized at the corporate level. A summary of the draft 
corporate plan is in Supplementary Appendix A. Government approval of CEB’s corporate plan 
in a form that is acceptable to ADB is a condition of effectiveness of each Loan and Grant 
agreement.

13.  Clean  Energy  Development. The country’s primary energy sources are indigenous 
biomass (47% of the total in 2003), imported petroleum products (45% in 2003) and hydropower

Lanka’s limited options are therefore more use of indigenous resources, less consumption of 
fossil fuels, and diversification into cheaper fuels. At the end of 2008, there were 73 small 
hydropower plants of 138 MW, one wind power plant of 3 MW, and three biomass plants of 12 
MW. It is estimated that the country has technical potential for 24,000 MW of renewable energy 
including biomass, wind and small hydropower plants. The TYDF aims to (i) increase the 
percentage of households electrified through the off-grid supply from 4% at present to 10% by 
2016; (ii) increase the share of nonconventional renewable energy in the on-grid power supply

14.  In October 2007, the Government established the Sustainable Energy Authority (SEA), a 
focal  agency  mandated  to  develop  and  implement  national  policy  for  renewable  energy 
development, energy efficiency improvements, and energy conservation. It also introduced new 
technology-specific  multi-tier  tariffs  to  attract  more  private  investment  to  nonconventional 
renewable energy projects. Although these initiatives have created an institutional framework to 
promote the development of renewable energy projects, lack of grid capacity remains a major 
technical bottleneck for clean energy development through private sector investment.  
 
15.  Transmission and Distribution Network Development. CEB completed a master plan 
study for the development of the transmission system in Sri Lanka in 2006 and prepared a long-
term  transmission  development  plan  (LTDP)  until  2015.  LTDP  has  identified  significant 
investment needs in the transmission system to (i) evacuate power generated from new power 
plants  planned  under  the  LGEP;  (ii)  improve  overall  system  reliability  and  efficiency;  
(iii) facilitate rural electrification; and (iv) facilitate grid integration of renewable energy projects. 
In 2008, the transmission and distribution loss was estimated to be 15% of net generation. 
These losses are partly technical, e.g., overheating cables and transformers, because of the 
excessive current caused by the unplanned connection of new customers, and by the non-
implementation of planned improvements to the network because of financial constraints. The 
Government  aims  to  reduce  the  overall  losses  to  12%  by  2016  by  accelerating  the 
strengthening of the transmission and distribution network. The Government will also make a 
parallel effort to upgrade and improve the meters and the metering system, and to strengthen 
surveillance to prevent theft, especially in suburban and rural areas.  
 
16.  Rural  Electrification. By the end of 2008, 82% of total households had electricity 
connections. Most of those without access to electricity lived in rural areas. The Government is 
committed to an interim target of 86% by 2010 and an ultimate target of 98% (88% on-grid and 
10% off-grid) by 2016. While some areas can be electrified by closing the gaps in the existing 
network, most villages yet to be electrified require off-grid electricity services. Another major

5
challenge in suburban and rural areas is low penetration in electrified villages. Even though 
distribution feeders have reached their neighborhood, many households remain unconnected as 
they cannot afford to pay connection charges. To reduce this financial burden, the Government 
plans to expand a credit support program piloted by an ADB-funded project.4 
 
17.  Demand-Side Management. The SEA is mandated to develop and implement policies 
to  reduce  consumption  and  achieve  better  energy  efficiency  in  residential,  municipal  and 
industrial users. The Government has identified eight priority areas: (i) power factor correction in 
transmission networks, (ii) efficiency improvements in lighting applications in residential and 
commercial  buildings and  lighting  grids,  (iii)  industrial  boilers,  (iv)  air-conditioning  systems,  
(v) compressed air systems, (vi) industrial motors and drives, (vii) fans and air blow installations, 
and (viii) municipal water and irrigation pumps and lighting systems. The Government also plans 
to promote compact fluorescent lamps (CFLs) and introduced mandatory labeling in 2007. It 
plans to complete the program by 2010. In addition, the Government is preparing to update the 
CFL program and to introduce a mandatory energy efficiency building code.  
 
18.  Debt Restructuring and Tariff Rationalization. In 2005, the Government wrote off 
SLRs7.8 billion of CEB’s deferred tax and other payment arrears to the Treasury and made 
direct payments of SLRs3.5 billion to the Ceylon Petroleum Corporation on behalf of CEB. The 
restructuring plan for CEB’s long-term debt of SLRs61 billion was approved by the Government 
in April 2006. Half of the long-term liabilities have been converted to equity and half have been 
rescheduled. At the end of 2008, CEB has a total long-term liability of SLRs 31 billion.  
 
19.   To  ensure  electricity  prices  reflect  the  cost  of  supply  and  improve  revenues,  the 
Government has rationalized the tariff structure so that all the recurrent expenses of CEB will be 
met by the tariffs. In March 2008, the Government introduced a new tariff structure increasing 
average retail tariffs by about 30%. The increases will mainly affect domestic consumers, who 
have been heavily cross-subsidized by commercial and industrial consumers. However, the 
impact on “lifeline tariffs,” considered necessary to maintain minimum living standards, has been 
minimized. Consumers with high domestic consumption have higher tariffs than those with low 
consumption. A fuel surcharge now applies to all consumers. This is a significant change, and 
gives the domestic consumer greater incentives to save energy. Under the Sri Lanka Electricity 
Act, all tariffs must reflect costs; the costs of any subsidy approved by the Government will be 
borne by the Treasury.

5.  Lessons 
 
22.  In 1998, the Government committed itself to carrying out sector reforms and embarked 
on a program to restructure the power sector by unbundling CEB into separate functional 
companies  and  establishing  an  independent  regulator.  The  Government  introduced  the 
Electricity  Reform  Act,  2002  to  provide  a  legal  framework  for  the  program.  However,  the 
unbundling of CEB did not materialize because of opposition from within the ruling coalition and 
from the powerful labor unions. As the act was designed to enable PUCSL to start regulation 
following the unbundling of CEB, regulatory reform has been at a standstill. As a result, in 2006 
ADB terminated the program loans to support the reform program as the second tranche 
conditions were unlikely to be fulfilled.     
 
23.  The main reason the previous reform program did not succeed was that a CEB trade 
union backed by a leftist party protested against the reform. Since the leftist party was a 
member of the ruling coalition, the Government made a political choice not to unbundle CEB. 
Some members of the Government and CEB who believed that the most pressing need was to 
build  a  cheaper  base  load  capacity  rather  than  to  carry  out  reform  also  influenced  the 
Government decision. Some stakeholders also perceived the reform process to be donor-
driven. 
 
24.  Based on the lessons learned from the previous reform attempt, ADB encouraged the 
Government to conduct intensive consultations with stakeholders when preparing a fresh sector 
development program. The Government prepared the NEPS and had it approved by Parliament 
to ensure ownership by all political stakeholders. The Government has taken a pragmatic 
approach to this round of regulatory reform and as a result has faced less political resistance.  It 
left CEB vertically integrated and delinked regulatory reform from the restructuring of CEB. It 
decided  to  introduce  the  Sri  Lanka  Electricity  Act,  designed  to  encourage  efficiency 
improvement by CEB by regulating each FBU. Recognizing these policy actions as a strong 
indication of the Government’s commitment to reform, ADB resumed its support for the power 
sector by approving a TA project6 in December 2007 and a country operations business plan 
which includes the current Project.  The Sri Lanka Electricity Act was passed by Parliament in 
March 2009 to complete the regulatory reform.

 3.  Scaling-Up Access for the Poor  
 
31.  In Sri Lanka, many households remain unconnected because they cannot afford to pay 
connection charges even though distribution feeders have already reached their neighborhood. 
However, some of these households may have the capacity to repay a loan or to pay the 
connection charges in monthly installments over 2–3 years. To address this issue, in 2004, ADB 
approved a microfinance scheme funded by the Japan Fund for Poverty Reduction—the Power 
Fund  for  the  Poor  (footnote  4).  The  fund  has  been  successfully  implemented  by  two 
participating credit institutions in collaboration with CEB and a local organization specializing in 
the energy sector and has electrified more than 10,000 poor households in eight districts while 
maintaining a recovery ratio of more than 95%. As evidenced by the high recovery ratio, target 
households are able to pay once they get connected, with technical and institutional support 
from the organizations involved. The Project aims to scale-up the fund through a loan-funded 
credit support program and is expected to provide electricity connection to at least 60,000 poor 
households, including those living in areas affected by conflict. This represents 8% of the total 
number of poor households. This will provide significant support to the achievement of the 
Government’s goal of increasing the household electrification ratio through grid connections 
from the present 82% to 88% by 2016.

LECO  could  fulfill  ADB’s  fiduciary  requirements  for  the  Project.  The  assessment  was  in 
accordance with ADB guidelines and used a financial management assessment questionnaire

E.  Potential Risks and Assumptions 
 
68.  The major assumptions are that (i) the Government will remain committed to power 
sector reforms; (ii) the long-term generation expansion plan (LGEP) will be implemented in a 
timely manner; and (iii) the Sri Lanka Electricity Act will be efficiently implemented for PUCSL to 
regulate the sector. 
 
69.  The Government’s commitment to sector reform is demonstrated by the fact that it has 
(i) provided financial support for the implementation of CEB’s long-term debt restructuring plan; 
(ii) submitted the NEPS for the parliamentary approval, which is not required for a policy 
document,  and  gazetted  it;  and  (iii)  substantially  increased  retail  tariffs  to  improve  CEB’s 
financial position. CEB has drafted its first long-term corporate plan, which it is using as a basis 
for its internal reform exercise. The Government has already secured financing for the priority 
projects in LGEP and three projects totaling 950 MW are being implemented. 
 
70.  Parliament has passed the Sri Lanka Electricity Act in March 2009 and PUCSL has 
started regulating the power sector. Although there is a risk that PUCSL and CEB make lack 
capacity to operate effectively under the new regulatory framework, this will be substantially 
mitigated by ADB’s technical assistance for capacity development of the two agencies and 
PUCSL’s experience in supporting the Government’s policy-making over the past 4 years.       
 
71.  Other  risks  to  the  implementation  of  the  investment  projects  include  (i)  delays  in 
associated generation investments, (ii) delays in project implementation and resulting project 
cost escalation, and (iii) a deterioration of the security situation in the Eastern Province. These 
risks also appear to be low. A policy and regulatory framework is already in place to streamline 
the Government approval process for renewable energy projects. SEA has been established as 
a focal agency for renewable energy development and is being supported by an ADB TA to 
expedite the review of the pending small hydropower projects that will be promoted by the 
Project.  All  the  subprojects  under  the  Project  are  ready  for  implementation  and  advance 
procurement will help expedite project implementation and mitigate the risk of cost overruns. As 
the Government is now taking full control in the Eastern Province, no difficulty is foreseen in 
implementing  the  subprojects.  The  associated  technical  assistance  will  help  design 
implementation arrangement of the projects.

  2.    Key Issues 
 
3.  About 20% of households do not have access to electricity, which is expensive and 
subject to interruptions. CEB is burdened with debt, restricting its capacity to make capital 
investments by CEB and discouraging private investments in the sector.  
 
4.  High Cost of Generation. The share of thermal power in the power generation mix has 
increased dramatically from 1% in 1986 to 58% in 2008 as the entire growth in demand has 
been served by oil-fired thermal generation. The 1998 policy of building thermal power plants

Poor  political  decisions  and  a  lack  of  financial  resources  have  prevented  CEB  from 
implementing the least-cost generation plan, using coal as the most economical source of 
energy.  The  move  toward  oil-fired  plants,  the  increase  in  the  oil  price,  and  the  delayed 
construction of new hydropower plants have significantly pushed up the cost of generation. 
There is an urgent need to build up base load generation capacity with low-cost fuels, such as 
imported coal, and to invest in hydropower and other renewable resources.  
 
5.  Skewed Tariff Structure. The dramatic increase in generation costs since 1998 has not 
been passed on to electricity consumers since the Government, as the regulator, has had 
neither the political will to pass on the cost increases to consumers nor the technical capacity to 
evaluate the CEB’s cost structure to decide on the appropriate level of tariffs. As a result, CEB 
has posted an operating loss since 2000 and accumulated its liability. Sri Lanka’s electricity 
customers, particularly commercial and industrial customers and large households, pay higher 
prices than most of their regional comparators. A reduction in the cost of supply is urgently 
needed, coupled with a stable and high-quality supply of electricity. 
 
6.  Inadequate and Aging Transmission and Distribution Network. Retail tariffs, which 
do  not  reflect  the  cost  of  supply,  coupled  with  CEB’s  institutional  weakness  in  project 
implementation, have continued to squeeze its investments in transmission and distribution. The 
low-voltage distribution network requires improvements if it is to meet the expansion in housing 
and commercial developments. Overdue investment in the medium-voltage distribution network 
has caused overloading, poor reliability and fluctuating voltage at many locations. The growth in 
demand for power distributed over the medium-voltage network requires a matching investment 
in the transmission network and grid substations. Immediate investments in the transmission 
and distribution network are needed, not only to reduce system losses and to ensure the 
stability  of  the  entire  power  system  but  also  to  encourage  private  sector  investment  in 
nonconventional renewable energy.   
   
7.  High Commercial Losses and Lack of Penetration in Rural Areas. The low customer 
density in suburban and rural areas causes higher network losses than in urban areas. In 
parallel with network strengthening, further efforts are needed to upgrade and improve meters 
and  metering  systems  and  to  enforce  strict  surveillance  to  prevent  theft.  Another  major 
challenge in rural areas is low penetration in electrified villages. Even in neighborhoods already 
reached by distribution feeders, many households remain unconnected as they cannot afford to 
pay connection charges.

  2.  Enabling Regulatory Environment and Sector Reforms   
 
8.  The Government established the Public Utilities Commission of Sri Lanka (PUCSL) in 
2002 as a regulator for the energy and water sectors under the PUCSL Act, 2002. However, 
although the act ensures the independent status of PUCSL staff, the final authority for issuing 
licenses  and  determining  electricity  tariffs  is vested  in  the  Government  (PUCSL  has  been 
advising the Government on policy decisions, including setting tariffs). In order to transfer these 
powers to PUCSL and to empower it to regulate the sector fully, Parliament has passed the Sri 
Lanka Electricity Act in March 2009. The first licenses to CEB, LECO, and the utilities will be 
issued within 6 months from its enactment.   
 
9.  CEB  has  converted  its  generation,  transmission  and  distribution  operations  into  six 
functional  business  units  (FBUs),  one  for  generation,  one  for  transmission,  and  four  for 
distribution. Financial accounts have been segregated so that each FBU will operate as a profit 
center. PUCSL will regulate each FBU separately and issue individual licenses. The board of 
CEB will delegate to the respective heads of the FBU all day-to-day management and the power 
to take all decisions to fulfill the obligations of the FBU under its license, including all financial 
powers to make capital and other investments, recruit personnel, and incur revenue expenses 
to the extent required to ensure the FBU achieves its revenue targets as approved by PUCSL. 
The board will also authorize the heads of FBUs to delegate some of the functions of the FBU to 
its officers. A memorandum of performance to be signed between the heads of FBUs and the 
board to ensure that FBU heads will (i) fulfill the license conditions; (ii) achieve the performance 
standards set by the regulator; and (iii) have both administrative and financial autonomy to 
manage the FBU within the stipulations of the license.

smaller share of the losses is due to connections without meters, metering errors, and theft. The

18.  Rural Household Connection. Many households in suburban and rural areas remain 
unconnected as they cannot afford to pay connection charges, even though distribution feeders 
have already reached their neighborhood. Traditionally, poor households have been a difficult 
group to target in the electrification campaigns because connections require initial capital that 
may be beyond the means of many families. However, some of these households may be able 
to repay a loan or connection fee in monthly installments over 2–3 years. Reaching these 
households would bring two major benefits. First, the households themselves will enjoy the 
benefits to be derived from having access to electricity. Second, CEB will have more customers, 
generating more income and enabling progress toward the electrification targets set by the 
Government. 
 
19.  In 2002, ADB approved a pilot project, the Power Fund for the Poor,4 which became 
operational in 2004. The project financed electricity connection costs for poorer households 
through a revolving fund administered by local microfinance institutions. As of the end of 2007, it 
had electrified 10,400 poor rural households in over 400 villages in eight districts. With support 
from ADB, the Government will continue to provide a credit support program to rural households 
to build on the success of this pilot project.

achieve better energy efficiency in residential, municipal and industrial end-user applications.

to  financing  for  energy  conservation  projects.  Eight  technology  priority  areas  have  been 
identified by the Government for pilot demand-side and energy conservation projects. These 
include power factor correction in transmission networks and efficiency improvements in lighting 
applications  in  residential  and  commercial  buildings,  lighting  grids,  industrial  boilers,  air 
conditioning systems, compressed air systems, industrial motors and drives, fans and air blow 
installations,  and  municipal  water  and  irrigation  pumps  and  systems.  Combined  with  loss 
reduction  programs  in  transmission  and  distribution  networks,  these  initiatives  can  reduce 
demand for imported fuels and mitigate environmental impacts associated with the increase in 
greenhouse gases, sulfur dioxide, and particulate matter emissions.

22.   Debt Restructuring. In 2005, the Treasury wrote off SLRs7.8 billion of CEB’s deferred

23.  Tariff  Rationalization.  To  ensure  electricity  prices  reflect  the  cost  of  supply  and

PROJECT DESCRIPTION OF DEMAND-SIDE MANAGEMENT PART 
 
A.  Background 
 
1.  Sri Lanka's generation capacity is projected to continue lagging behind the demand 
requirements over the near to medium term. The planned enhancement of generation capacity 
will be derived mainly from new coal-burning thermal facilities and, as a result, the share of 
clean energy in power generation will decrease. It is therefore crucial to mitigate the impacts 
associated  with  this  substantial  enlargement  of  greenhouse  gas  emissions  through  rapid 
demand-side management to reduce end-user consumption and losses in transmission and 
distribution networks.  
  
2.  Responsibility  for  street  lighting  traditionally  rests  with  local  authorities  such  as 
municipalities, town councils, and pradeshiya sabhas. Electricity bills are paid out of government 
subsidies so municipalities have no incentive to reduce energy consumption. In addition, the 
Government has not been able to pay the full amount of subsidies, which has led to commercial 
losses for CEB and LECO. In the case of CEB, the energy consumed by street lighting system 
is estimated at 150 GWh per year. Out of this, about 52 GWh are unaccounted for, adding an 
extra 0.57% to CEB system losses. To put an end to this vicious cycle, the Government has 
decided to delegate responsibility for municipal street lighting to CEB and LECO, starting in 
selected urban areas.  
 
3.  Under the project, CEB and LECO will establish internal units based on a utility energy 
service  company  (ESCO)  model  to  undertake  the  street  lighting  operations  and  maximize 
energy savings through demand-side management. The ESCO service market is still quite 
immature in Sri Lanka, and requires further strengthening and support from external partners. 
The  utility  ESCO  model  to  be  set  up  with  ADB  assistance  will  be  used  for  demand-side 
management programs for municipal governments and other customers with capital constraints. 
 
B.  Impact and Outcome  
 
3.  The energy savings from the project will help reduce the commercial losses of CEB and 
LECO. The outcomes will be (i) a reduction in energy consumption and related costs and 
implementation of energy efficiency improvements in municipal street lighting systems, and (ii) 
freed additional capacity and peak load stabilization within distribution networks in the program 
areas.  
 
C.  Outputs 
 
4.  The project will support the implementation of pilot energy efficiency projects in the CEB 
and LECO service areas, and have the following outputs:  
 
(i)  separation of street lighting feeders and installation of feeder meters; 
(ii)  replacement of old conductors and feeder controls; 
(iii)  replacement  of  incandescent  and  mercury  evaporation  lamps  with  compact 
fluorescent or sodium lamps to save energy and ensure longer performance (the 
lamps last five times longer than incandescent lamps); and 
(iv)  installation  of  time-of-day  switches  and  electronic  timers  to  cut  electricity 
consumption during the daytime, eliminate overcharging, remove delays caused 
by manual switching of lamps, and ensure reliable operating schedules.

SUMMARY OF ECONOMIC ANALYSIS 
 
A.  Background and Approach 
 
1.  The power supply industry in Sri Lanka is vertically integrated and is owned primarily by 
the Government with the exception of a few generating stations owned and operated by private 
companies. Ceylon Electricity Board (CEB) is the national utility. It owns and is responsible for 
the generation, transmission, and approximately 90% of the distribution of electrical power in Sri 
Lanka. Lanka Electricity Company (LECO) was formed as a distribution company under the 
Companies Act and most of its shares are owned by CEB and the Government.  Municipal 
authorities are minority shareholders  
 
2.  The CEB transmission system comprises a 220 kV and 132 kV transmission network 
connected to grid substations and power stations. However, underinvestment and delayed 
investments  are  causing  severe  constraints  on  the  operation,  reliability,  and  quality  of  the 
electricity supply. Development and strengthening of the primary transmission and associated 
grid substation facilities are essential to meet the suppressed and growing electricity demand.  
 
3.  The  proposed  transmission  system  investments  are  consistent  with  ADB’s  country 
partnership strategy and provide a least-cost intervention to improve physical infrastructure.1 
Electricity is a prerequisite for GDP growth as well as for rural and urban development, and an 
adequate power supply is essential for increasing private sector investment in industry and 
commerce, and for promoting agro-industrial activity and off-farm employment. The importance 
of improving the efficiency of the electricity system has been heightened by the rapid rise in 
world fuel prices over the past 5 years. These have affected Sri Lanka badly as over 58% of its 
power  supply  comes  from  relatively  small,  high-cost,  diesel-fired  generating  plants.  By 
upgrading the transmission system, removing bottlenecks, and improving system efficiency, the 
proposed investments can contribute the government’s efforts to provide better services at an 
affordable price. As electricity transmission is a natural monopoly under the direction of CEB, a 
public sector intervention to fund the needed investments is justifiable. 
 
4.  An economic analysis was undertaken for the investment components. The analysis 
sought to determine and verify: 
(i)  electricity demand and supply projections;  
(ii) that the proposed subprojects are part of the national least cost expansion program; 
(iii) economic cost benefit analysis including sensitivities to key variables; and 
(iv) distribution of costs and benefits amongst stakeholders.  
 
5.  Economic benefits will accrue from the cost savings resulting from displacing more 
expensive sources of energy due to the system improvements, and incremental benefits from 
greater electricity consumption.  
 
B.  Demand Forecast 
 
6.  Overall annual electricity demand grew from 823 GWh in 1972 to 5,416 GWh in 2000, 
representing an annual compound growth rate of about 7%. Since then it has grown at about 
8% per annum to the current 8,458 GWh.2 CEB prepared a national power and energy demand

C.  Least-Cost Planning 
 
7.  CEB’s long-term transmission development plan for 2006–2015 identified the upgrades

8.  All  costs  and  benefits  are  expressed  in  constant  2009  prices.  The  domestic  price

were converted to domestic equivalents using an estimated standard exchange rate factor of

financial charges during construction. 
 
E.  Project Benefits 
  
9.  The Project’s investment outputs can be categorized into three groups, with the first 
group  enjoying  slightly  different  economic  benefits:  (i)  system  upgrades,  including  the 
augmentation  and  construction  of  grid  substations  and  transformer  capacity  enhancement; 
(ii) construction of new transmission lines; and (iii) construction of the new system control 
center. 
 
10.  The  primary  benefit  of  grid  substation  augmentations  and  transformer  capacity 
enhancements  are  the  reduction  in  unserved  demand.  This  demand  will  now  be  met  by 
increasing the transmission capacity by eliminating transmission bottlenecks from the existing 
“without-project” scenario, and by enabling the grid to accommodate the anticipated demand 
growth  over  time.  This  incremental  power  supply  is  valued  using  consumers’  estimated 
willingness to pay for incremental consumption. 
 
11.  The primary benefit from the new transmission lines is the power flow improvements, 
and the resulting elimination of diesel-fired power generation that is required in the “without-
project” scenario. The need for small, local diesel generators for voltage correction in the 
respective transmission constrained areas will be eliminated by the construction of new lines, 
which will allow grid power to flow into these areas. This produces a resource cost saving for 
CEB when grid-supplied power costs are compared with the higher-priced, small-scale, diesel-
fired generation that they will replace. As with the new system control center, this represents a 
non-incremental output of electricity to consumers, and is valued as a resource cost savings 
that accrues if these transmission lines are built. CEB estimates the marginal cost of these 
captive diesel plants to be SLRs18.65/kWh. Another benefit of these new transmission lines is 
that they will be able to handle the anticipated load growth on CEB’s system. However, this 
benefit cannot be valued on its own; it will have to be considered as part of CEB’s long-term 
integrated  power  system  expansion  program,  encompassing  generation,  transmission  and

12.  The primary benefit of the new system control center will be increased system efficiency 
and reduced transmission network losses. The new control center will enable proper system 
management, and voltage and reactive power optimization. To value these benefits, the quantity 
of extra power that would have had to be generated to make up system inefficiencies and

is from incremental power sales due to reduced system outages and reduced restoration times 
when outages occur. However, this benefit is very small compared with the resource cost 
savings (about 0.3% of total calculated benefits). 
  
13.  The cost of electricity in Sri Lanka is very high because of dependence on diesel-fired 
base load generation and oil price increases. In such a high-cost environment, resource cost 
savings  produce  high  upfront  economic  benefits.  It  is  projected  that  the  average  cost  of 
electricity will decrease over time, as the planned addition of coal-fired generation will lower 
average system costs.3 In the economic analysis, high upfront resource cost savings decrease 
over time. 
 
F.  Estimation of Willingness to Pay 
 
14.  The  estimation  of  willingness  to  pay  used  the  methodology  outlined  in  the  ADB 
Economics  and  Research  Department’s  technical  note  Measuring  Willingness  to  Pay  for 
Electricity.4 The economic benefits of electricity consumption are based on the alternative costs 
of energy used in the absence of grid-supplied electricity. Estimates of these benefits require 
theoretical  demand  curves  for  electricity  use  by  various  consumer  categories.  Taking  into 
account  the  value  of  alternative  fuel  sources  to  satisfy  suppressed  demand,  in  the  rural 
domestic context, the cost of kerosene illumination was used. In the commercial and industrial 
context, the cost of diesel generators was used.  
 
15.  Two methods were employed to estimate willingness to pay (further detail is available in 
Supplementary Appendix F). First, demand functions relating energy price to energy demand 
were  estimated  for  each  of  the  three  main  consumer  groups  in  Sri  Lanka  (domestic, 
commercial, and industrial).5 Average price and consumption data for the past 5 years were 
adjusted for income and inflation to arrive at a common 2009 base. Consumption data were 
scaled for estimated suppressed demand.6  Regression analysis was used on the data points to

consumers) and SLRs16.34/kWh (industrial consumers), with a weighted average value based 
on power usage of SLRs18.9/kWh. However, as this regression analysis used a limited number 
of years of data, alternative approaches are recommended and their results compared. Second,

Although this project is not designed to be a targeted intervention, a number of key elements will ensure it has positive 
impacts on poverty. The distribution substation in Colombo will increase the power reliability, from which both public 
consumers (such as social services) and private consumers (households and businesses) will benefit.  
 
Transmission system enhancement will also have positive impacts, since some important areas will be now reached by the 
national grid, particularly the Eastern Province and Pallekelle industrial district. In the first case, the Government is expecting

domestic water pumps, and backyard farms and small cottage industries will benefit.  
 
This component is expected to improve the living standards of poor households, by improving health conditions, reducing 
expenditure on power (on-grid electricity is cheaper and more reliable than kerosene), increasing their productivity and 
income, and increasing the number of hours children can study at night. 
 
Non-electrified households in Sri Lanka use kerosene oil for domestic lighting so electrification will lead to savings in the use

C.  Policy Framework 
 
6.  The  Project  will  follow  both  ADB’s  Involuntary  Resettlement  Policy  (1995)  and  the 
relevant Sri Lankan laws and policies. Until 2001, project-related resettlement issues were 
guided by Land Acquisition Act, 1950, as amended from time to time.  However, as this did not 
have adequate provisions for the full social and economic rehabilitation of the people to be 
resettled, Sri Lanka has adopted a National Involuntary Resettlement Policy (NIRP), which 
requires a resettlement plan to be included in the approval process if a project affects more than 
20 families.1  The policy assigns the overall responsibility for its implementation to the Ministry of 
Land  Development,  with  the  project-approving  agencies  and  the  Central  Environmental 
Authority also being assigned responsibilities for evaluation and implementation. 
 
7.  In addition to the NIRP, a cabinet decision in 2006 (amended in 2007) covered payment 
of compensation for families affected by land acquisition for power sector development projects 
and works connected with electrical undertakings. No involuntary resettlement is foreseen in this 
project, but, in case any involuntary resettlement becomes unavoidable, compensation will be 
paid in accordance with the NIRP and the cabinet decision.

H.  Monitoring and Evaluation 
 
11.  The Environmental Unit of the CEB will coordinate all environmental and social issues 
pertaining to the Project. The CEB will provide the required human and financial resources to 
ensure that the Environmental Unit will accomplish these requirements. The Project Director will 
be responsible for the following: 
 
•  To formulate a monitoring framework for environmental and social issues. 
•  To prepare inception and periodical M&E reports and to submit them to ADB for review. 
•  To facilitate the generation of required data and information for preparing the M&E 
reports. 
•  To Liaise with CEA and other relevant agencies in conducting M&E. 
•  To hire qualified external monitors for annual monitoring of the environmental and social 
issues including involuntary resettlement issues. 
 
 
12.  The  environmental  unit  will  provide  assistance  and  play  a  coordinating  role.  The 
assistance of environmental experts will be obtained when necessary, to handle special issues, 
particularly those related to impacts on biodiversity in sensitive areas.
